project.teaser: As the solid waste management crisis is growing in its urgency, humanitarian aid practitioners are faced with the question of how to manage environmental challenges linked with aid that is being shipped across various humanitarian settings. One of the sound solutions how to...
project.objective: As the solid waste management crisis is growing in its urgency, humanitarian aid practitioners are faced with the question of how to manage environmental challenges linked with aid that is being shipped across various humanitarian settings. One of the sound solutions how to address this challenge is to open up a streamline of cooperation between humanitarian aid operators and the bio-based sector allowing them to explore the application potential of bio-based products, systems, and innovative technological solutions. Bio4HUMAN aims to contribute to the identification of bio-based solutions for solid waste management that have the potential to be applicable in various humanitarian settings. To achieve this goal, Bio4HUMAN will conduct a scoping exercise that will come up with a list of solutions but also identify existing supply chain gaps. Following that, it performs life cycle assessments of the proposed solutions and evaluates their applicability with regard to socio-economic and governance aspects. To explore if solutions fit the purpose of key solid waste management stakeholders and to explore the possibility of their acceptance by the community, local businesses, and local authorities, Bio4HUMAN conducts a feasibility evaluation process in 2 African locations. Simultaneously, the project will develop a replication roadmap that will contribute to the future replicability of the solutions identified. Altogether, all of the Bio4HUMAN’s actions will help to improve ways of addressing waste management challenges under humanitarian contexts and to the reduction of waste littered in the environment. In the long run, Bio4HUMAN is expected to contribute to the development of innovative and sustainable value chains that will benefit consumers and citizens in Europe and beyond.
project.title: Identifying bio-based solutions for waste management applicable to humanitarian sector
project.keywords: bioproducts, solid waste management, circular economy

details.authors: López-Hermoso, Estela; Bearzotti, Chiara; Monzó Sánchez, María Fuensanta; Barranca Jiménez, Alberto; Carpio Vallejo, Estefania; Bartolomé, Carla; Mennella, Mara

result.title: Bio4HUMAN Dissemination, Communication and Exploitation plan

details.authors: Pęczek, Tadeusz; Gajek, Anna; Kuznowicz, Damian; Bądel, Agnieszka; Sobczyk, Paweł

result.title: Dissemination, communication and exploitation plan
result.description: An objective-oriented plan for dissemination, communication and exploitation of project results, aiming at maximizing the project’s impact. Will be constantly updated during the project. The reference task is T7.1.

result.title: Humanitarian sector needs assessment report
result.description: Humanitarian sector needs assessment report with regard to SWM that will be build from a detailed literature review on SWM in humanitarian settings, field work done by PAH and PIN (focus groups, key informants’ interviews) with community members and local authorities. The information for the report will be also collected from government institutions and non-government agencies, civil society organisations, and when needed 1:1 interviews and consultations will be carried out. The reference task is T3.3

result.title: Data collection from partners: state-of-the art and innovative solution
result.description: This deliverable consists of the data collection template, as well as the compilation of data collected for innovative solutions during T5.1. The reference task is T5.1.

result.title: Scoping plan
result.description: Detailed scoping and its communication plan will be developed which will be included in overall D,C,E plan. This scoping plan will outline the objectives, specific methods that will be used to collect and analyse data from both bio-based sector and humanitarian aid sector, scope statement, a refined timeline for the scoping and details on how the results will be reported and shared with key stakeholders identified in T3.1. It will also identify potential risks and limitations and propose ways to mitigate them. The reference task is T3.2.

result.title: Practice Abstracts – batch 1
result.description: This deliverable containts First Practice Abstract of the project in the EIP-AGRI format to allow checking the appropriateness of the Bio4HUMAN content and text for end-users. The reference task is T7.3.

result.title: Mid-term policy brief
result.description: Policy recommendation report, outlining Bio4HUMAN's advise for policy makers regarding the applicability of practical tools to address further R&D&I needs and socioeconomic considerations that will showcase the growing potential of bio-based products and systems usage across diverse humanitarian contexts. The reference task is T4.3.

result.title: Gap analysis report
result.description: This deliverable will report on the identification of gaps and the areas for innovative approaches. It will define the dimensions and point scales that will be devised and agreed specifically for the scoping exercise. It uses a common data extraction sheet and simple rating scheme (constituted by the humanitarian sector priority areas) with these dimensions and point scales. The reference task is T4.3.

result.title: D4.1 List of bio-based solutions Annexes 1-9

details.authors: ITENE, Enspire, WeLOOP, PIN, PAH, PRO CIVIS

result.title: D3.3 Humanitarian Needs Assessment Report Annexes 1-10

details.authors: Anna Nejedla, Marie Smidova Skalova, Ludwika Klejnowska, Anna Gorska, Damian Kuznowicz, Artur Sobolewski, Pilar Villanueva Redón, Andrea Motola, Carolina Szablewski, Kim Luu
Pęczek, Tadeusz; Gajek, Anna; Kuznowicz, Damian; Bądel, Agnieszka; Sobczyk, Paweł

result.title: Data management plan
result.description: Description of the type of data generated, collected and/or (re)used, and compliance with FAIR principles. The . The reference task is T1.1.

result.title: Project website
result.description: A project website will be created by Enspire with the aim of marketing the project and its activities across Europe. The website will be kept up to date. The project will use a free website performance assessment to examine the data where the users are coming from. Based on that, the consortium will strategize the project's marketing efforts. The website will offer a subscription for the project newsletter. The reference task is T7.2.

result.title: Stakeholder analysis
result.description: This deliverable is a result of T3.1 Mapping the key stakeholders. It will contain information about the key stakeholders in DRC, South Sudan and in Europe. It will focus on analysis of the stakeholders that 1) are potential producers of bio-based solutions in target areas 2) will be affected by the implementation of the solutions (communities, international and national humanitarian NGOs, local authorities) 3) government, and public bodies on national and EU-level involved in policy making for: the sustainable products regulations, regulations and standards for SWM, securing allocation for funding for humanitarian aid and advocating the implementation of effective SWM. The reference task is T3.1.

result.title: Periodic Reporting for period 1 - Bio4HUMAN (Identifying bio-based solutions for waste management applicable to humanitarian sector)
result.teaser: Bio4HUMAN’s overarching objective is to provide humanitarian aid operators and bio-based sector stakeholders, with science-based information on the application potential, sustainable performances, and circularity of bio-based products and systems, suitable for humanitarian...

category.title: Report Summary
category.description: Result: Publishable summary (FP7 SESAM) and Summary for publication (H2020 SyGMa)

details.authors: Anna Nejedla, Marie Smidova Skalova, Ludwika Klejnowska, Anna Gorska, Damian Kuznowicz, Artur Sobolewski, Pilar Villanueva Redón, Andrea Motola, Carolina Szablewski, Kim Luu

result.title: List of bio-based solutions
result.description: This report will present a list of identified already existing technological solutions (or solutions being in the pre – production phase which could respond to the needs of the sector identified in T3.3 and the identification of supply chain gaps in SWM system for humanitarian action. The reference task is T4.2.

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
